Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for the ACM/IEEE SEC 2017 Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2017 IEEE SEC Conference (Symposium on Edge Computing) will be held in San Jose, CA on Oct. 12-14, 2017. This preeminent technical conference is the primary venue for presenting new research results in the area of "edge computing", a new paradigm in which the resources of a small data center are placed at the edge of the Internet, in close proximity to mobile devices, sensors, and end users, and the emerging Internet of Things. Participants will have the opportunity to present their work, attend panel and keynote sessions, and interact with many people conducting leading-edge research in the field.

To help build student participation, particularly at institutions where travel funds may not otherwise be available, the plan is to support 20 students. Participation in conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience providing students' exposure to senior researchers and leading edge work in the field.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Binghamton
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to support travels of US-based students to attend the ACM/IEEE Symposium on Edge Computing (SEC), which took place in San Jose, CA on Oct. 12-14, 2017.

We received 24 applications for the travel grant from students in the US institutions. In the end we awarded 24 students to receive the grant. The average amount of support is $830 each. All the supported students attended the conference and the poster/demo session.

The following students were awarded this grant:

Archit Manish Gajjar (University of Houston-Clear Lake)
Arvind Ramesh (University of Pennsylvania)
Bo Mei (George Washington University)
Bozhao Qi (University of Wisconsin-Madison)
Chih-Peng Wu (Texas A&M University)
Christopher Streiffer (Duke University)
Gorkem Kar (Rutgers University)
Hossein Badri (Wayne State University)
Jianyu Wang (University of Missouri-St Louis)
Karim Habak (Georgia Institute of Technology)
Lanyu Xu (Wayne State University)
Lele Ma (College of Willam & Mary)
Lixing Chen (University of Miami)
Lucas Chaufournier (University of Massachusetts Amherst)
Pengzhan Hao (Binghamton University)
Pradipta Ghosh (University of Southern California)
Qiang Liu (University of North Carolina-Charlotte)
Shanhe Yi (College of Willam & Mary)
Tayebeh Bahreini (Wayne State University)
Wei Wang (University of Maryland-Baltimore County)
Wuyang Zhang (Rutgers University)
Yang Deng (University of North Carolina-Charlotte)
Zheng Dong (University of Texas-Dallas)
Zhuo Chen (Carnegie Mellon University)

A photo of part of the student awardees at the conference is attached.


Last Modified: 12/10/2018
Modified by: Yifan Zhang

All the supported students attended the conference and the poster/demo session.
